newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: KOREA FIRST TO RESTORE FINANCIAL STATUS.
newsitem.headline: KOREA FIRST TO RESTORE FINANCIAL STATUS.

text.p: Korea First Bank, hit by a chain of corporate defaults this year, announced a self-rescue programme on Saturday to generate a total of 512.5 billion won over the next three years, a bank statement said.
The nation's leading commerical bank said it would sell off some of its assets and subsidiaries, reduce the number of employees, close some overseas offices and merge several branches at home.
The bank had unveiled a similar plan in May when it was badly hurted by the failure of Hanbo Steel and Sammi Steel early this year. The bank's employees agreed to freeze wage rises.
A Korea First Bank spokesman said the bank needed a larger scale rescue plan after creditors agreed in July to protect the financially troubled Kia Group from imminent defaults until September 29.
During the period, Kia would not be required to service its debt.
Korea first bank is a major creditor of the Kia Group.
Korea First Bank said it would reduce the number of employees by 1,100 during the three years, which would help the bank save 65 billion won.
By selling its assets including real estate holdings, the bank planned to raise 173.3 billion won.

In addition to earlier plan to sell three subsidiaries including KFB Securities, Korea First Mutual Savings and Finance Co, and Korea First Venture Capital Corp, the bank would also sell Korea First Lease and its stake in an affiliate in Vietnam.
The statement said the sales would contribute 117.5 billion won.
In order to reduce overhead expenditure, the bank would hold off new investments, which were not urgent, and cut the number of branches nationwide to 412 by merging 13 units.
The bank will also close its offices in Burma and in Jackson Heights of New York.
